conclusion: Two identical books A and B, each weighing 5N, are divided into equal parts and alternately stacked on a smooth table. Book A is fixed, and a horizontal force F is applied to pull out book B.
The coefficient of kinetic friction μ is defined as the ratio of the sliding friction force f to the pressure N, μ = f/N.
The coefficient of kinetic friction μ between any two sheets of paper in the two books is equal.
The image shows two books, A and B, divided into various equal parts. A horizontal force F is applied to pull out book B.
The data indicates that the force F is proportional to the reciprocal of the number of divisions, with specific values provided.
Books A and B are divided into parts, with book B being pulled using a force F.
The force F required to pull out book B decreases as the number of divisions increases.
F is inversely proportional to the number of divisions n, so F = k/n, where k is a constant.
Using the data for 3 divisions, F = 10/3 N, so k = 10.
The force F required to pull out book B is F = 5 N when divided into 2 equal parts.
The sliding friction force f is equal to F in this scenario, so f = 5 N.
Given μ = f/N, and N = 5 N, μ = 5/5 = 1.
